awd_titl_txt: Integrating novel molecular techniques to disentangle the roles of climate, time, and human agency on the evolution of the Icelandic landscape
awd_abstract_narration:
Project Abstract

Non-Technical Description:
Significant uncertainties remain in our ability to predict how ecosystems will respond and landscapes will change as the Arctic continues to warm faster than the global average.  We can look to past warm times in recent Earth history to better constrain how the Earth system will respond to warming over the coming century. At the end of the last ice age Earth's orbit was such that the Northern Hemisphere received nearly 10% more solar energy in summer than at present. That extra energy was sufficient to melt almost all Iceland's glaciers, and the Sagas say birch forests extended from the shores to the mountains. Molecular compounds that track changes in temperature, aridity, and vegetation history are contained within the sediment deposited in Icelandic lakes and nearby composite soils over the past 12,000 years. These "proxies" provide a means to accurately reconstruct a continuous history of climate and ecosystem status across Iceland since the end of the last ice age. This research benefits from recent advances in the recovery of DNA from sedimentary archives and in organic geochemistry to isolate biomarkers that track temperature and moisture balance. A pervasive feature of the contemporary Icelandic landscape is widespread soil erosion, but whether that erosion is a result of human settlement and pastoral activity or climate change remains debated. Geochemical proxies related to soil erosion preserved in well-dated lake sediment are targeted to disentangle the roles of climate and humans in Iceland's soil erosion history. This project helps launch an early-career Latino scientist, provides international exposure to a recent PhD as postdoc in a DNA laboratory in Norway, and supports a new PhD student, as well as supporting and mentoring motivated undergraduate students, who gain research experience in a highly relevant field. With an embedded journalist communicating the potential effects of climate change derived from this research to the wider public is enhanced. 

Technical Description:
The Arctic is currently warming twice as fast as the global average with summer temperatures predicted to be 4 to 6 degrees C above late 20th Century averages by the year 2100.  Amplified warming in the Arctic is expected to result in a northward shift in woody plants. The increase in woody vegetation will reduce surface albedo and increase atmospheric water vapor, positive feedback mechanisms that are currently poorly constrained in climate models. In Iceland, stratified, securely-dated, lake sediment records span the current interglacial (Holocene) and contain a rich archive of sedimentary ancient DNA (sedaDNA) and lipid biomarker proxies for temperature (brGDGTs), hydrology (delta2-Hwax) and human agency (fecal sterols and PAHs). The analysis of modern soil and lake surface sediment networks will provide calibrations that enhance the community's understanding of these promising new molecular proxies and facilitate the development of regional training sets. Merging the local calibrations with similar measurements downcore in lake sediment and stratified aeolianites will enable reliable reconstructions of past ecosystems and their dependence on summer temperature and hydroclimate. The novel integration of these datasets will provide transformative new insights into 1) how much warmer was the early Holocene in Iceland relative to today, 2) when and to what elevation woody plants established themselves during early Holocene warmth, and 3) to what extent climate, volcanism and/or Norse settlement led to the widespread soil erosion apparent across the Icelandic landscape today. Anticipated results from this project provide key datasets needed to inform policy and improve forecasts of a rapidly warming Arctic.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report Federal Award 1836981: Integrating novel molecular techniques to disentangle the roles of climate, time, and human agency on the evolution of the Icelandic landscape 

 

The island of Iceland was late to be settled by humans, with the best estimate for human colonization to have occurred ca. 870 CE by Norse sea-faring folk. Since settlement, Iceland has experienced major volcanic eruptions and times of very cold summers, particularly in what is known as the Little Ice Age (ca. 1450 -1850 CE) when Iceland glaciers advanced to their maximum extent since the end of The Last Ice Age ~11,000 years ago. Our project had two primary research objectives: 1) To disentangle the impacts of human settlement of Iceland and late Holocene cooling on widespread soil erosion and landscape disturbance that is prevalent today. And 2) To evaluate the arrival time of woody shrubs to Iceland following deglaciation, and whether early Holocene summer warmth (9000-5000 years ago), long before settlement, allowed woody shrubs to colonize elevations well above the current tree elevational limit. We used sediments preserved in four strategically located lakes that were deposited over the past ~10,000 years, that contain organic geochemical biomarkers (branched glycerol dialkyl glycerol tetraethers (brGDGTs)) to reconstruct temperatures in the past, and ancient DNA preserved in the sediment to reconstruct ancient ecosystems and how those ecosystems evolved in response to natural climate change and to the potential impacts of human settlement of Iceland.     

         We tested whether the physical characteristics of the lakes influenced how our climate and environmental proxies record changes in the past by selecting two adjacent lakes, only 1 km apart, in the lowlands of NE Iceland at similar elevations (151 vs 144 m asl), but with very different geometries:  SVID is a large (2.5 km2), deep (48 m) lake with a 17 km2 catchment, whereas LVID is a smaller (0.2 km2), shallower (2.5 m) lake with a smaller catchment (2 km2). If there are significant differences in how climate and regional ecosystems respond to natural and/or anthropogenic disturbances, this will allow us to assess whether the choice of lakes from which to sample for our key proxies can make a major difference in how those proxies record climate and human activities over time. We found that there were contrasts in oxygen levels between our two lakes that impacted the preservation of ancient DNA, with shallow lakes more susceptible to past changes in oxygen availability that can lead to fragmentary DNA records, but that the primary environmental records were broadly similar in the two lakes.

         We used ancient DNA preserved in the lake sediment of several lakes to make significant contributions to the current debate on the efficiency of woody plant establishment in Arctic regions during past warm times. Using our own, and published work of others, we showed that woody plant colonization of newly exposed lands is highly genus-specific, with Willow (Silicaceae) established efficiently as soon as new lands are exposed (whether by deglaciation or postglacial uplift as earth rises locally in response the the removal of a substantial ice load that depressed the crust), whereas Birch (Betula), the other common erect shrub, is often delayed by 1 or 2 thousand years behind willow (Harning et al., 2023). This has implications for how rapidly woody plants may migrate poleward as global warming continues.

         There is also a long debate within Iceland whether Betula (Birch) trees were more widely distributed than at present when Iceland was first colonized. We targeted a lake at 440 m asl in NE Iceland, where Betula does not currently grow for a sediment core to test whether conditions were suitable for Betula and colonization vectors efficient enough that Betula was established there during the Early Holocene when summer solar energy was 8 or 9 percent higher than at present. We used tephrochronology and radiocarbon dating to derive a chronology for the core, and ancient DNA preserved in the sediment, which together documented the presence of Betula growing around the lake as early as 8000 years ago. The ability of woody plants to migrate upward elevationally is an important consideration for future warming as there are strong positive feedbacks on greenhouse warming with the establishment of woody trees both elevationally and latitudinally in areas currently devoid of woody plants.  This will help us better predict how natural feedbacks in a warming world may accelerate or retard the rate of warming.  

         We found that for NE Iceland, where sheep farming was widespread but population densities were never very high, the impact of natural climate variability through the Holocene, primarily the reduction in summer insolation at high northern latitudes over the past 10,000 years, was the dominant driver of environmental change, rather than the establishment of human settlement and farming after 870 yr in the Common Era.
